trial_identification.studytitle: Micronutrient supplementation for improving micronutrient status in underweight and overweight/obese primary school children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of a multiple micronutrient supplement on the micronutrient status of underweight and overweight/obese primary school children in Vietnam a randomised controlled trial

conditions.healthcondition: Micronutrient status of primary school children

interventions.interventions:
Intervention: a multiple micronutrient supplement
Composition of each capsule: 12.5 mg iron, 10 mg zinc, 400 micrograms vitamin A, 0.5 mg vitamin B1, 0.5 mg vitamin B2, 0.5 mg vitamin B6, 0.9 microgram vitamin B12, 30 mg vitamin C, 5 micrograms vitamin D3, 5 mg vitamin E, 150 micrograms folic acid, 6 mg vitamin B3, 0.56 mg copper, 90 micrograms iodine and 17 micrograms selenium. One capsule will be consumed by each participant five times per week (Monday to Friday) for six months.
Adherence: school staff will administer the supplement (1 capsule) to each child every day (Monday to Friday) for six months. School staff will monitor and record if the supplement has been taken; both empty and unused blister packs will be collected from school staff to further assess adherence. A blood sample will be taken at the beginning and end of study to confirm the effectiveness of the supplement in increasing haemoglobin concentration, and improving iron, zinc, vitamin A and other micronutrient status.
interventions.comparator: Placebo (placebo capsule) administered to each child five times per week (Monday to Friday) for six months. Adherence will be monitored as in the intervention group.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.
Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.
Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome [4]: Vitamin A status (assessed by serum retinol).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint [4]: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome [5]: Vitamin D status (assessed by serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint [5]: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome [6]: Selenium status (assessed via serum selenium).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint [6]: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome [7]: Serum/plasma concentrations of other micronutrients (composite outcome: serum copper, serum iron, serum folate).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint [7]: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Growth (assessed by height, weight and z-scores).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Body composition (assessed by triceps skinfold thickness, mid-upper arm circumference and waist circumference).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dietary intakes (assessed via a 24-h recall collected for 7 days at 4 time points).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured for 7 days at baseline, and at 1.5, 3, and 5 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Morbidity and health status (assessed via daily health/illness records collected by school health staff, daily health/illness records collected by parents; school absence recorded by school staff; and C-reactive protein concentration measured at baseline and at 6 months.
Physical activity (assessed via a 24-h recall collected for 7 days at 4 time points).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured for 7 days at baseline, and at 1.5, 3, and 5 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cost-benefit analysis (analysis based on calculating total expenditure for the intervention and benefits gained from improvements in micronutrient status in the intervention group).
Cognitive function (assessed by a visual recall task)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline and at 6 months after intervention commencement.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dietary pattern (assessed via a Food Frequency Questionnaire that assessed intakes over the previous 7 days).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Primary school children aged 6-9 years Apparently healthy Haemoglobin concentration <110 g/L
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Haemoglobin concentration <70 g/L Current/planned vitamin and mineral supplementation Chronic disease Chronic infection Congenital abnormality Severe malnutrition

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Micronutrient deficiencies are a major health problem among underweight children in Vietnam. Similarly, overweight/obese children are at an increased risk of micronutrient deficiencies. This is of concern because both underweight and overweight/obesity affect many school children in Vietnam. The aim of this study is to assess the effect of a multiple micronutrient supplement on the micronutrient status of underweight and overweight/obese primary school children in rural areas in Vietnam.
